stories.headline: Will city keep controversial gunshot-detection system?
stories.summary: As Sacramento considers whether to continue with its multimillion-dollar gunfire-detection technology, there is debate over its effectiveness and impact on communities. While law enforcement values its quick response capabilities, critics argue the system often results in false alerts and has no clear effect on reducing gun violence. The city’s current contract is set to expire amid broader scrutiny of police practices.

stories.headline: Sacramento braces for triple-digit temperatures
stories.summary: Sacramento is expected to experience a heat wave with temperatures reaching up to 102 degrees, marking a return to triple-digit heat in the region. This weather pattern is forecasted to last into the weekend, bringing potentially the hottest days of the year. Meteorologists warn residents to prepare for the increased heat which could impact health and safety.

stories.headline: Sacramento County postpones Natomas housing project vote
stories.summary: A planned vote by Sacramento County on a controversial housing project in Natomas has been postponed. The project, opposed by many local residents and officials, involves building at least 9,000 new apartments and houses in the area. The delay follows strong community criticism and aims to allow more time for review. The decision has sparked debate on growth, infrastructure, and community impact in Sacramento County.

stories.headline: City leaders question ICE about detained immigrants sleeping on floor
stories.summary: Sacramento city officials have raised concerns with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) regarding reports that some detained immigrants have been forced to sleep on the floor under poor conditions. Local leaders have requested transparency and better treatment for those detained at the John E. Moss federal building. The situation has attracted criticism from community advocates and government representatives demanding humane treatment.

stories.headline: New director chosen for 'vision'
stories.summary: The Dallas Museum of Art has appointed Brian Ferriso as its new director, succeeding Agustin Arteaga. Ferriso brings extensive experience from his previous role at the Portland Art Museum and is set to lead the DMA through a $140 million renovation and expansion project. He emphasizes a community-focused approach and aims to enhance the museum's role within Dallas' civic and cultural landscape, continuing the momentum set by his predecessor.

stories.headline: Coalition bows out of zoning dispute
stories.summary: The Save Pepper Square Neighborhood Association in Far North Dallas has voluntarily dropped its lawsuit against the city of Dallas and developer Henry S. Miller, ending a contentious, years-long fight over the $200 million redevelopment of Pepper Square. The coalition cited factors including money and new development laws as reasons for dropping the suit, which marked the end of a prolonged battle over plans to turn the retail strip into a mixed-use site with nearly 900 apartments.

stories.headline: House approves new map
stories.summary: The Texas House passed a new congressional redistricting plan that could flip five Democrat-held districts to Republican control in the 2026 midterm elections. The plan aims to shift certain districts in North Texas, Houston, San Antonio, Austin, and South Texas, with a partisan vote of 88-52. The new boundaries could turn Democrat seats into Republican wins and head to the Senate next. This move follows President Donald Trump's victory, with the GOP hoping to increase their seats in the U.S. House of Representatives.

stories.headline: 'I lied to her,' mom of camper tells panel
stories.summary: Carrie Hanna, a Dallas mother, testified before a Senate panel on disaster preparedness regarding safety reforms for youth campgrounds, sharing the tragic loss of her daughter and others in a flash flood at Camp Mystic. She detailed the lessons learned and emotional impact as families seek changes to prevent such disasters, emphasizing the importance of camp safety. Her testimony highlights the ongoing push for reform after the tragedy that affected many children and families.

stories.headline: Pastor resigns before test of IRS rule
stories.summary: Jonathan Barker, a pastor from Kenosha, resigned after planning to endorse a progressive presidential candidate in violation of new IRS guidance on political endorsements during church services. His resignation followed opposition from church leadership and potential legal risks to the church. Barker has been outspoken on various social issues and previously protested for climate change policies. His resignation underscores tensions between religious activism and IRS rules.

stories.headline: State releases $16 million to MPS
stories.summary: Milwaukee Public Schools received $16.6 million of the $42 million they had withheld from the district as state officials progress in reviewing late financial reports from the 2023-24 school year. While some reports are still incomplete, the state Department of Public Instruction was able to make payments based on unaudited data, marking progress under the district's new leadership. MPS has moved to improve its financial reporting and administration despite challenges earlier in the year.

stories.headline: FANS OF BREWERS, FREE BURGERS
stories.summary: Fans of the Milwaukee Brewers formed a line outside George Webb Restaurant on South Howell Avenue on August 20 to redeem free burgers. The giveaway was triggered by the Brewers winning 12 games in a row, extending their streak to 14 games.

stories.headline: Floods can't stop woman from bringing reading, books to Milwaukee's children
stories.summary: Dannette Justus continued her mission to promote children's reading in Milwaukee despite severe flooding that damaged her home in early August. She resumed her weekly online reading sessions, a tradition started during the COVID-19 pandemic, and remains committed to her nonprofit 'Just Us and Books'. Justus emphasizes resilience and the importance of managing emotions while maintaining her dedication to literacy efforts.

stories.headline: DELIVERING FRUIT, THEN DETAINED
stories.summary: Rodrigo Minguela Palacios, a strawberry delivery driver in Little Tokyo, was detained by Border Patrol agents who happened to see him during his delivery route. The incident has caused a rift in his family and sparked criticism of the Trump administration's immigration enforcement tactics in urban areas, along with efforts to intimidate political opponents.

stories.headline: Some voters see red over districts
stories.summary: Republicans in rural Northern California are opposing Governor Gavin Newsom's redistricting plan, expressing concerns about losing control and the impact on representation for areas like Shasta County and neighboring counties. The article highlights the political tensions and demographic changes influencing this opposition.

stories.headline: Redistricting push advances in Texas
stories.summary: Texas Republicans are advancing a plan to redraw congressional maps that would advantage their party and potentially marginalize Democratic voters. The Texas GOP-controlled House of Representatives is supporting this move despite protests and calls for transparency, with approval likely on an 88-52 party-line vote.

stories.headline: An alternative to police
stories.summary: Early efforts in Los Angeles to use unarmed crisis responders show promise in handling mental health related calls and non-violent situations. This alternative approach aims to reduce the burden on law enforcement and improve outcomes by prioritizing compassion and safety through specially trained teams.

stories.headline: SUVs take CHP undercover
stories.summary: The California Highway Patrol (CHP) deployed 100 new Dodge Durangos disguised as civilian vehicles to better detect and stop reckless drivers. These SUVs lack standard patrol markings, which helps CHP officers to more effectively prevent dangerous driving behaviors, especially impaired and 'ghost-riding' drivers.

stories.headline: Ex-fire chief claims unjust removal
stories.summary: The former Los Angeles fire chief filed a legal claim alleging she was defamed and unjustly removed by Mayor Karen Bass. The claim details accusations of a campaign of misinformation and retaliation leading to her dismissal. The mayor's office denies these allegations and asserts decisions were based on ongoing personnel and operational issues.

stories.headline: Davis, Zerwas named to posts
stories.summary: The University of Texas System Board of Regents approved Jim Davis as the new UT president and John Zerwas as the chancellor of the University of Texas System. Both candidates served as interim leaders before their appointments and were selected through a process allowed under the regents' rules. Davis has a long history with the institution and expressed gratitude for his new role leading the prestigious university.

stories.headline: Judge blocks display of Ten Commandments in classrooms
stories.summary: A federal judge issued a temporary block on a new Texas law requiring schools to display posters of the Ten Commandments in classrooms. The law would also allow a lawsuit by families and faith leaders opposing the mandate. The judge ruled that the state's law likely coerces school children into observing a faith and pressured the religious beliefs of students, and further legal proceedings will decide the law's future.

stories.headline: Testimony: Trust in safety ‘betrayed’
stories.summary: Families of children who died during the July 4 floods at Camp Mystic testified at the Capitol, expressing their anguish and claiming their trust was betrayed due to a lack of safety regulations at the Christian summer camp. CiCi Steward and her husband shared about their daughter Cile, one of the flood victims, highlighting the devastation caused by the floods in the Texas Hill Country. The testimony emphasized the emotional toll on the affected families and the need for accountability.

stories.headline: House passes new redistricting map
stories.summary: The Texas House passed a new congressional map led by Texas Republicans that aims to boost their power in Congress by removing five Democratic-held districts in Austin, Dallas, Houston, and South Texas. The bill passed 88-52 after Republicans voted to limit debate, with the map ordered by President Donald Trump and endorsed by Gov. Greg Abbott. This sets up a national fight over congressional redistricting as Democrats opposed the map.

stories.headline: Haverford College facing antisemitism inquiry
stories.summary: The U.S. Department of Education has launched an investigation into Haverford College over its handling of antisemitism complaints following allegations of anti-Jewish bias. The probe is part of a broader review of reported discrimination and harassment against Jewish students, amid ongoing investigations into similar issues at other U.S. colleges.

stories.headline: Army unit straining to meet Hegseth's security needs
stories.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s personal security needs are placing unusual demands on the Army Criminal Investigation Division (CID). Officials say the protective measures are unlike any other seen recently, requiring long assignments to safeguard family residences and manage investigations. This strain is creating operational challenges within the agency.

stories.headline: Flood warnings? Beach restrictions? Making the best of it at the Shore
stories.summary: Visitors at the Jersey Shore encountered clouds, rain, and choppy seas before Hurricane Erin's approach. Despite restrictions like bans on ocean swimming due to shark risks and dangerous weather, visitors such as Joe and Debi DeRenzine have adapted by taking shelter and making the most of their vacation at the shore.

stories.headline: Justice Dept. demands trans patients' records
stories.summary: The Justice Department is demanding that hospitals turn over extensive sensitive information related to medical care for transgender patients, challenging the Trump administration's right to such data. Children's Hospital of Philadelphia and other entities have raised concerns about privacy for this vulnerable population amid subpoenas seeking detailed patient communications and records.

stories.headline: Israel to Call Up 60,000 Reservists for Gaza Move
stories.summary: Israel has initiated the call-up of 60,000 reservists in preparation for potential military actions near the Israeli-Gaza border, as tensions remain high and hundreds of thousands of Palestinians are believed to be sheltering amidst the conflict.

stories.headline: Investors Doubt a Lifelong Insider At Target Can Shepherd Turnaround
stories.summary: Target faces skepticism from investors about its ability to turnaround under the leadership of Brian Cornell, a lifelong insider who succeeded the previous CEO. Shares of Target fell after disappointing sales figures and concerns about competition from Walmart and Amazon.

stories.headline: Trump Weighs Firing A Fed Governor
stories.summary: President Trump is considering firing Lisa Cook, a Biden-appointed Federal Reserve governor, if she does not resign following accusations of mortgage fraud. Trump has expressed determination not to be bullied, and this potential move has raised concerns about political interference in the Federal Reserve.

stories.headline: Russia Resists Kyiv Security Plan
stories.summary: Russia has refused to participate in security guarantees for Kyiv despite efforts by the White House and Kremlin's acceptance for a peace deal. Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov rejected a U.S. security guarantee plan and criticized Ukraine's national-security team's proposals amid ongoing tensions.

stories.headline: Scotts Miracle-Gro Prunes Pot-Growing Product Line
stories.summary: Scotts Miracle-Gro, once known for its cannabis-growing products, has decided to cut back its pot-growing product line. The company, led by Jim Hagedorn and his son Chris, is shifting focus amid changing perceptions and corporate branding strategies related to legal cannabis.

stories.headline: Capitol security panel convenes
stories.summary: A new committee on Capitol security has convened to address concerns over weapons screening and security measures following recent attacks on lawmakers. The committee, which includes lawmakers and officials, discussed the potential addition of weapons-screening systems, with further decisions expected in coming months. The discussions reflect ongoing efforts to enhance safety at the State Capitol.

stories.headline: Trump: Fed governor should quit
stories.summary: President Donald Trump has publicly called for the resignation of Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook, citing unverified allegations related to her past mortgage fraud engagement. The demand came as Trump intensified his campaign to remake the central bank leadership. Lisa Cook and another Black governor, Beryl Pulte, are under scrutiny amid these political pressures, with investigations ongoing into alleged falsifications of loan documents.

stories.headline: Growth is target for new CEO
stories.summary: Michael Fiddelke has been selected as the new CEO of Target, succeeding Brian Cornell. Fiddelke, who is already leading Target's efforts to improve financial results, will focus on regaining the market's credibility and enhancing in-store shopping experiences through technology. The company aims to overcome recent profit declines and a challenging retailer landscape dominated by Walmart and Amazon.

stories.headline: 'C' grade for Chain of Lakes is an environmental victory
stories.summary: The Chain of Lakes in Minneapolis, once severely degraded, has seen a remarkable environmental turnaround over the past 30 years. Efforts to restore the lakes have reversed decades of damage caused by urban runoff and development. The transformation is celebrated as a success in preserving one of the most visited natural sites in Minnesota, improving the area's ecological health and public enjoyment.

stories.headline: House passes new map to redraw districts
stories.summary: The Texas House passed a new congressional map aimed at increasing GOP seats, overcoming Democratic protests that stalled previous attempts. The map, backed by Governor Greg Abbott and President Donald Trump, was approved 88-52 despite opposition citing unfair congressional redistricting and challenges in recent days from both parties.

stories.headline: $600K settlement reached in HHA suit
stories.summary: A whistleblower lawsuit against the Houston Housing Authority was settled for $600,000. The suit accused the agency of fraud involving paying contractors without oversight. Board members voted to approve the payment, part of an ongoing effort to address internal issues following a housing authority memorandum.

stories.headline: Judge blocks Ten Commandments law
stories.summary: A federal judge in San Antonio temporarily halted a Texas law requiring public schools to post the Ten Commandments in classrooms, citing concerns over discrimination against children perceived as 'the other.' The ruling emphasizes that Texas school districts cannot coerce employees or others into displaying religious texts, as part of upholding constitutional rights.

stories.headline: Testimony: Trust in safety ‘betrayed’
stories.summary: Families of Camp Mystic children who died in the July 4 floods testified to a Senate committee, expressing how safety regulations at a Christian summer camp were lacking. The mother of the only missing child spoke emotionally about her loss and the betrayal felt from leadership as multiple generations of women from the family had attended the camp.

stories.headline: Lancton draws conservative support at campaign kickoff for county judge
stories.summary: Firefighter-turned-union leader Patrick "Marty" Lancton launched his campaign for Harris County judge with strong backing from local conservative groups. Supported by notable Texas leaders, Lancton emphasized safety, fiscal responsibility, and collaboration with state and local leaders to enhance county administration if elected in 2026.

stories.headline: After Battle to Get to the Top, Why Did She Sell Paramount?
stories.summary: Shari Redstone, daughter of a billionaire mogul, sold her stake in Paramount Global after little more than a year at the helm. Despite overcoming challenges and steering the company through critical transitions, she chose to step away, marking the end of a notable chapter in media industry leadership.

stories.headline: Democrats See Profound Loss In Registration
stories.summary: The Democratic Party is hemorrhaging voters long before they even go to the polls. Analysis shows that in 30 battleground states, Democrats lost ground to Republicans between the 2020 and 2024 elections, with a particularly deep political hole in some blue and red states. This shift is attributed to fewer Americans choosing to be Democrats and complex voter registration dynamics.

stories.headline: Russia Taking Territory While It Can
stories.summary: A Ukrainian woman was evacuated from the eastern region of Donetsk after her village was attacked by the Kremlin's forces, highlighting the escalating conflict in the area and the ongoing turmoil faced by civilians caught in the war zone.

stories.headline: Lining Up to Be a One-Stop Shop for Streaming
stories.summary: Streaming services are rapidly evolving with millions tuning into platforms offering combined services that include live sports and other content. Subscribers increasingly opt for single-provider packages, enhancing convenience and reshaping the consumer experience in entertainment streaming.

stories.headline: Trump Shrinks Student Access From Overseas
stories.summary: Many Iranians and students from China and India face challenges accessing American universities as the U.S. State Department tightens control on international student enrollment. This causes concern among universities and students about future access and cooperation.

stories.headline: Moves By Israel Risk Imperiling Hope For Peace
stories.summary: Israel approved new settlements in the West Bank and moved to take over Gaza City, actions that sparked criticism and raised questions about the potential for a cease-fire proposal. These moves are seen as driven by hard-liners and complicate peace prospects as violence continues.

stories.headline: Ireland's Last Leprechaun Whisperer Hunts His Own Pot of Gold
stories.summary: Kevin Woods from Carlingford, Ireland, claims to have interacted with leprechauns during his childhood. Now, he shares stories and organizes tours about the legend of leprechauns in the region, keeping local folklore alive while attracting curious visitors.

stories.headline: Virility Aids Pose Health Risks
stories.summary: Concerns rise over unregulated sexual stimulants being marketed as herbal remedies or pharmaceuticals in West Africa. Health officials warn these products may pose significant health risks, emphasizing the need for caution and regulation.

stories.headline: Hong Kong Curbing Discontent
stories.summary: Authorities in Hong Kong warn that some resistance movements are operating covertly and warn that such activities threaten security. The government focuses on controlling unrest to maintain order in the region.

stories.headline: Seeking Fed Governor’s Ouster
stories.summary: The Trump administration has accused an official, Lisa Cook, of mortgage fraud and called for an investigation, intertwining political disputes with regulatory oversight.

stories.headline: Quite the Captive Audience
stories.summary: A climate-themed play titled "Arborlogues" features each participant performing a 15-minute monologue for a tree, engaging audiences and raising awareness about environmental issues.

stories.headline: New Fans Discover Deftones
stories.summary: The band Deftones, known for their 90s metal scene presence, continue to captivate new audiences and hold nostalgia among longtime fans, maintaining their influence in music.

stories.headline: Created 007's Signature Logo
stories.summary: Joe Caroff, a graphic designer who developed the iconic '007' logo and created numerous posters for the James Bond franchise, is remembered for his creative contribution to the film series.

stories.headline: Fan Week Gets a Makeover
stories.summary: The U.S. Open reimagines its traditional free preview offering low-key qualifying matches, reinventing the format to spotlight some of the biggest names in tennis drafted into the event.

stories.headline: Immigrants seeking legal work, citizenship now subject to ‘anti-American’ screening
stories.summary: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services will implement new policy screening immigrants legally seeking work, citizenship, and other legal statuses for 'anti-American' behavior. This broad and vague criterion raises concerns about potential discrimination and has been linked to the Trump administration’s tough immigration stance, sparking debate over transparency and civil rights implications for immigrant communities.

stories.headline: Two Haitian cops are killed after ‘kamikaze’ drone explodes
stories.summary: Two Haitian police officers were killed and six others injured after a homemade drone exploded in the hills near Port-au-Prince during a gang-fighting operation. The incident highlights the escalating violence and complex security challenges facing the region, with armed gangs reportedly abducting people and authorities struggling to maintain control.

stories.headline: ‘Rewrite history.’ Miami historians alarmed about review of Smithsonian exhibits
stories.summary: Historians in Miami express alarm over the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture’s review of exhibits that include artifacts connected to Florida’s history. Concerns arise around reinterpretation and potential minimization of important historical items such as those related to Muhammad Ali, Florida A&M University band, and African American cultural symbols, amid broader debates on addressing historic racial injustices and preserving truthful narratives.

stories.headline: ‘This is a crisis.’ Miami-Dade mayor warns funding fix for the arts is short-term
stories.summary: Miami-Dade’s arts community faces uncertainty as Mayor Daniella Levine Cava and local arts leaders express concern over a budget proposal aiming to cut art-grant funding and dissolve the county’s cultural-affairs department. Despite public outcry and town hall meetings, the mayor warns that the originally planned spending for 2026 has already been significantly reduced, and the fate of the county’s arts funding remains unstable with the possibility of further cutbacks.

stories.headline: Israel's military to call up 60,000 reservists
stories.summary: Israel's military announced a significant mobilization calling up 60,000 reservists in response to escalating military needs amid a Palestinian conflict in Gaza. The call-up aims to support operations and humanitarian efforts while responding to ongoing regional tensions and an expanded military operation.

stories.headline: FTC accuses Pikesville firm of ticket-scalping scheme
stories.summary: The Federal Trade Commission accused a Pikesville-based ticket broker in a lawsuit of using thousands of fake accounts to buy up Swift concert tickets and resell them at higher prices, deterring fair access to tickets. The broker, Key Investment Group, maintains that its ticket resales are legitimate, with an ongoing legal examination by the FTC.

stories.headline: Erin stays offshore
stories.summary: Sea water from Hurricane Erin caused flooding and coastal hazards in Buxton, North Carolina, as the storm approached the mid-Atlantic coast and then churning waves further north. The National Weather Service issued warnings for the coastal risks.

stories.headline: President calls on Fed Reserve official to resign
stories.summary: President Donald Trump called on Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook to resign after a member of his administration accused her of committing mortgage fraud, illustrating ongoing tensions between Trump and the central bank. Bill Pulte, overseeing mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, and the Justice Department continue investigations. The Federal Reserve declined to comment on the accusation.

stories.headline: Hale switches parties, plans Republican run for governor
stories.summary: Businessman Ed Hale Sr., who previously announced a Democratic campaign, said he is now running as a Republican for governor of Maryland. Analysts note that a party flip could impact political dynamics. Hale made the switch ahead of primary events and highlighted his support for other Republicans in the state.

stories.headline: Moore's trade trip to Asia cost $322,000
stories.summary: Governor Wes Moore's international trip to Japan and South Korea cost Maryland taxpayers about $322,000, exceeding budget by $72,000. The Baltimore Sun's review highlighted costs including flights, accommodations, and travel for 19 people. Despite costs, Moore's administration and supporters emphasized the strategic importance of the trip for improving investments and international agreements.

stories.headline: Trump's stance on mail-in vote stirs battle
stories.summary: President Donald Trump's latest push to end absentee voting has ignited heated criticism and a fierce debate about election rules ahead of the 2026 and 2028 election cycles. Experts say the president has no legal role in running elections. Advocacy groups are threatening lawsuits over the issue while Democrats prepare for political fights leading to the upcoming midterm and presidential campaigns. Constitutional concerns about states' powers to run elections are also part of the debate.

stories.headline: Delray isn't budging on Pride crosswalk — for now
stories.summary: The rainbow-painted Pride crosswalk in downtown Delray Beach will remain for at least a few more weeks. City commissioners voted Tuesday night to hold an administrative hearing on September 2 before deciding on its potential removal. The Florida Department of Transportation has ordered the removal citing safety concerns and road surface irregularities. The issue has sparked debate about compliance with state government authority and political expressions in public spaces.

stories.headline: DOGE chief says he's uncovered wasteful spending in the county
stories.summary: Blaise Ingoglia, Florida's chief financial officer, revealed that his auditors have found 'eye-popping' examples of inappropriate spending in Palm Beach County. However, he declined to specify these examples, stating a full report will be available within about 60 days. Ingoglia is overseeing audits conducted by Florida's Department of Government Efficiency under an executive order by Gov. Ron DeSantis.

stories.headline: Small town gathers together to remember library friend
stories.summary: In the small town of Prescott, the community held a funeral for Libby, a pet tortoise lost in a fire that destroyed the local library building, causing grief as the library was a vital part of the town. The fire was sudden and unexpected, and despite no known cause, the loss deeply impacted the residents who gathered to remember the cherished pet and express their sorrow over the destruction of the library.

stories.headline: Fed governor with MSU ties faces Trump’s fire
stories.summary: Lisa Cook, a Fed governor with ties to Michigan State University, is under scrutiny as President Donald Trump asked her to resign from her Federal Reserve post. Cook is accused of mortgage fraud by Bill Pulte, a Trump appointee and director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency. Cook has a strong academic and leadership background, and the controversy adds to the ongoing dialogue about political influence in federal appointments and economic policy in Detroit and beyond.

stories.headline: Another CEO faces concert scandal
stories.summary: A woman has filed a lawsuit against a married corporate executive under allegations of sexual harassment at a Detroit concert. The woman, Stephanie Starling, accuses the executive, a CEO of a hotel company, of inappropriate behavior including groping and intimidation following a Justin Timberlake concert. Starling lost her job after reporting the incident and is taking legal action against the executive and related companies over the behavior and its fallout.

stories.headline: Missouri governor picks state's first woman attorney general
stories.summary: Missouri Governor Mike Kehoe announced Catherine Hanaway as the state's next attorney general, effective Sept. 8, becoming the first woman to hold the position. Hanaway, a former federal prosecutor and Missouri House speaker, replaces Andrew Bailey, who is set to join the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Hanaway has over 20 years of experience and is recognized for her political insight and service to Missouri, holding key positions including state leadership and working with the FBI during the Trump administration. Her appointment represents a significant milestone in Missouri politics.

stories.headline: Looming fare comeback makes 79-year-old bus rider uneasy
stories.summary: Sadie Grant, a 79-year-old Kansas City resident, is uneasy about the Kansas City Area Transportation Authority's plan to reinstate bus fares in 2026 after years of free rides. Grant relies heavily on the bus system for shopping and visiting friends but finds the service unreliable with broken amenities and infrequent schedules. While the KCATA buses provide essential transportation to many, the proposed fare adjustments raise concerns for riders like Grant who depend on affordable transit options.

stories.headline: Teacher charged with assault taught at 4 other districts
stories.summary: A Park Hill middle school physical education teacher, Isaiah Christopher Washington, faces three counts of misdemeanor assault for allegedly making sexual advances toward students since 2013. Washington worked in four different Missouri school districts and holds educator certification. Multiple students reported feeling trapped and uncomfortable due to his behavior, including sexually suggestive comments and hugs against their will. Court records reveal at least seven students shared uncomfortable incidents with investigators.

stories.headline: What happens if Jackson County executive White is recalled?
stories.summary: Jackson County voters will decide whether to recall county executive Frank White Jr. for the first time, with the Sept. 30 election prompted by a petition calling for his removal. The recall election could limit polling places and voting machines, eliciting warnings from local election boards. White previously told a Kansas City newscaster he plans to retire by the end of 2026 if not recalled. The recall effort has gathered over 43,000 signatures, surpassing the required threshold representing 20% of voters.

stories.headline: Vice president visits National Guard troops
stories.summary: President Donald Trump's law-enforcement crackdown on Washington expanded as top administration officials visited National Guard troops supporting a deployment to the U.S. capital amid escalating tensions and anger in the city. Vice President JD Vance and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth shared burgers with soldiers at the city's main railroad hub and met last Friday with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Alaska and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy. The visit aimed to bring law and order back under tense conditions.

stories.headline: Financial disclosure
stories.summary: Contributions for Decatur mayoral candidates total almost $122K ahead of Tuesday's municipal elections. Mayoral candidate Kent Lawrence leads with $82,784 raised, followed by Billy Jackson at $39,054. Candidates who do not cross the $1,000 threshold do not have to report contributions or expenses. Butch Matthews reported a single $100 contribution to the Secretary of State. The election is Tuesday.

stories.headline: Rottweiler attacks 6-year-old
stories.summary: A neighbor's dog attacked Becky Shackelford's grandson last week and might have killed him if it weren't for her husband's intervention. The 6-year-old was riding his bicycle when the Rottweiler, which weighs over 100 pounds, jumped their fence and ran toward him. The boy's grandfather intervened just in time to prevent serious injury. Cloud Control calls for stronger laws to identify aggressive dogs and penalize negligent owners.

stories.headline: NATO defense chiefs hold discussion on security guarantees
stories.summary: NATO defense chiefs held a candid discussion regarding security guarantees they could offer Kyiv to help forge peace agreement that ends Russia’s three-year war on Ukraine. Italian Admiral Giuseppe Cavo Dragone chaired the meetings, emphasizing the importance of Western military support including weapons and training to help Ukraine defend itself. Russian Foreign Minister Serge Yavrov criticized Moscow's stance and rejected collective security issues without Russian Federation involvement. Discussions also involved diplomacy and coordination of multinational support efforts.

stories.headline: Newsom stands out by being aggressive
stories.summary: Governor Gavin Newsom has launched a campaign to redraw California's congressional districts, placing himself at the forefront of the national political discussion. While this move aims to build a strong national donor base and boost his visibility in preparation for a potential 2028 presidential run, it carries risks. Experts warn the strategy could backfire if voters see it as a power grab rather than a constructive effort, and it may face resistance within the Democratic Party.

stories.headline: Breaking ground on $105M makeover
stories.summary: The India Basin Waterfront Park project in San Francisco is set for completion in 30 months, featuring a new beach, boathouse, pier, and playground. This $105 million makeover involves renovating a 7-acre hill and 10 acres of parkland, making it the city's most expensive park project. The three-phase renovation aims to revitalize the area and provide new recreational facilities, marking a significant community development milestone.

stories.headline: State mulls measure for hunting invasive swans
stories.summary: California is considering a measure to hunt invasive mute swans, which threaten the health of wetlands in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta and other areas. These large birds, native to Europe and Asia, weigh up to 30 pounds and have rapidly expanded their population, posing ecological risks. The plan aims to control the growing swan population to protect native wildlife and preserve wetland habitats.

stories.headline: Source: Macy’s in Corte Madera eyed for housing
stories.summary: A major redevelopment plan is underway for the former Macy's site at 1400 Redwood Highway in Corte Madera, Marin County. The 7.5-acre site, located within the Village at Corte Madera shopping center, is being considered for a mixed-use development involving housing, following a decline in department store retail use. Prado Group, with experience in retail and housing projects, is leading the effort, which aims to transform the area while preserving community business relations.

stories.headline: Texas House approves new voting maps that favor GOP
stories.summary: The Texas House approved redrawn congressional maps that would likely favor Republicans by giving them a larger edge in the 2026 midterm elections. The maps were approved following a push from President Donald Trump, who demanded revisions to the previous congressional map. Democrats argued the maps were a gerrymander favoring the GOP and protested by boycotting votes and attending round-the-clock police monitoring. The final approval passed by an 88-52 party-line vote.

stories.headline: Monsanto settles with over 200 exposed to chemicals in school
stories.summary: A major settlement announced this week has ended a lengthy battle between chemical manufacturer Monsanto and students, parents, and staff of a Monroe school who were exposed to toxic PCBs for years. The lawsuit claims that man-made toxicants led to cancer, brain damage, and death. Monsanto is accused of withholding information from the public about the toxicity of PCBs. More than 200 people from Sky Valley allege serious illnesses from exposure to these toxicants and have launched a legal campaign against Monsanto.

stories.headline: Russia makes relentless push into Ukraine to grab as much land as it can before talks
stories.summary: President Vladimir Putin of Russia is pressing forward to capture as much land as possible along a front line that stretches about 750 miles in Ukraine. Russians are deploying drones and troops in the critical eastern city of Pokrovsk and surrounding areas, aiming to gain territorial advantage before potential peace talks. Despite surges of surveillance, the Ukrainian forces regroup and resist. The conflict continues to escalate as larger formations of Russian troops outflank some Ukrainian defenses, posing a threat to the front line in this longstanding conflict.

stories.headline: 14 with state ties deported to 'third countries,' Gitmo Bay
stories.summary: A University of Washington report reveals that 14 immigrants with Washington connections were deported by the federal government to third countries, the U.S. detention camp at Guantánamo Bay, and South Sudan amid the Trump administration's increased deportation efforts. These deportations occurred via chartered flights out of Boeing Field or commercial flights from Seattle-Tacoma International Airport. The report calls for transparency and the end of collaboration between local authorities and federal immigration agencies.
people: University of Washington Center for Human Rights

stories.headline: Protesters call on Microsoft to cut ties with Israel
stories.summary: Dozens of activists have protested at a plaza in Microsoft's campus for the second consecutive day, urging the company to sever ties with the Israeli government. The protest involved setting up encampments and highlighted the use of Microsoft's military applications and support for Israeli military actions. Some activists threatened not to stop until Microsoft divests from Israeli engagements. The Redmond Police Department arrested 18 people in connection with these protests, including groups like No Azure for Apartheid.

stories.headline: Great Lakes Advocacy Group Warns That AI Will Be a Drain on Drinking Water Supplies
stories.summary: An advocacy group focused on the Great Lakes region has issued a warning that the rise and expansion of artificial intelligence could significantly strain drinking water supplies. The report outlines potential impacts and calls for proactive measures to manage water resources responsibly.

stories.headline: City Council Should Start Policing Its Own Members’ Bad Behavior, City Watchdog Advises
stories.summary: A city watchdog has advised that the City Council should begin policing the bad behavior of its own members to improve accountability and governance. The recommendation suggests internal reforms to better address misconduct within the council.

stories.headline: Emission Accomplished? State Trying Out Mobile Vehicle Testing, Self-Serve Kiosks in Chicago
stories.summary: The state is experimenting with new mobile vehicle emission testing and self-serve kiosks in Chicago as a potential advancement in emission oversight. This initiative aims to offer more convenient and efficient emissions testing options to vehicle owners.

stories.headline: Ever-evolving Nine Inch Nails Show Off Range — And Rage — in First of Two UC Shows
stories.summary: The band Nine Inch Nails showcased their evolving musical range and intense performance style in the first of two shows at the University of Chicago. The concert highlighted the band's ongoing artistic development and powerful live presence.

stories.headline: Swim Pickings
stories.summary: Abrupt early closing of some Park District pools highlighted a much shorter summer swimming season for some than others — and it's becoming a trend. This story discusses the variations and reasons behind the early pool closures across Chicago's Park District.

stories.headline: Donbas deal risks fortifying Russian power
stories.summary: A deal ceding Ukraine's Donbas region to Moscow is seen as potentially strengthening Russian military power by providing a strategic foothold on the Black Sea. It could bolster Russian control over mineral deposits and allow for a military buildup, undermining Ukraine and Western interests. The U.S., Ukraine, and Europe may push for a buffer zone to prevent further Russian expansion. Analysts express concern about the long-term security implications of such a deal.

stories.headline: Zelenskyy remains wary but relieved by security pledge, European unity
stories.summary: Ukrainian leaders express cautious optimism following a U.S. and European security pledge after President Zelenskyy's visit to Washington. Despite recent challenges including missile strikes damaging civilian areas, hope remains for a unified approach to Ukraine's defense and eventual peace. Officials emphasize the importance of guarantees and support to uphold Ukraine's security amid ongoing conflict with Russia.

stories.headline: India resets relations with China as Trump tariffs chill U.S. ties
stories.summary: India has resumed diplomatic and trade engagements with China, including direct flights and visa issuances, signaling eased tensions after recent border clashes and strained U.S.-India ties caused by Trump's tariffs. Indian and Chinese officials agreed on cooperation and mutual respect during recent talks, aiming to stabilize regional relations despite global geopolitical shifts.

stories.headline: Fed signals rate cut as job growth falters, Trump pressure rises
stories.summary: The Federal Reserve is considering cutting interest rates after slowing job growth, as the White House urges for easier monetary policy to support the economy. Fed Chair Jerome Powell is expected to address concerns about inflation, employment, and trade tensions, balancing pressures from market volatility and political demands ahead of upcoming financial meetings.

stories.headline: Former cops recall distorted statistics
stories.summary: Two lawsuits from former Metropolitan Police Department officers accuse the department of suppressing violent crime statistics, suggesting that police brass manipulated data to make the city appear safer. The cases challenge claims by D.C. officials and Democrats that crime is low, alleging officials downgraded violent crimes in reports to compete for federal funds. The suits underscore concerns about transparency and accountability in crime reporting.

stories.headline: IN GOP congressman pushes Trump for Nobel
stories.summary: Indiana Republican Rep. Marlin Stutzman has joined other lawmakers in nominating former President Donald Trump for the Nobel Peace Prize. Stutzman, representing the 3rd Congressional District, and others highlighted Trump's diplomatic efforts during his first term, including summits with Russia, Ukraine, and North Korea. The Nobel Prize announcement is expected in October, with several world leaders already nominated. The nomination follows ongoing global diplomatic developments, including involvement in ceasefire efforts and peace summits.

stories.headline: Despite resistance, national forest sees timber sales begin
stories.summary: The U.S. Forest Service has started timber sales in the Hoosier National Forest despite opposition from advocacy groups and Gov. Mike Braun, who called the project misguided. The timber auction is part of a forest management plan promoting tree growth and disease reduction. Local environmentalists warn the project could jeopardize the quality of drinking water relied upon by 130,000 Hoosiers. The Forest Service declined immediate comment but has delayed response time on inquiries. Experts emphasize that inaction is not a option for sustaining the forest amid climate change and invasive species.

stories.headline: Court: School didn’t violate anti-abortion teen’s rights
stories.summary: The Seventh Circuit court ruled that Noblesville High School did not violate a student's rights when it suspended her anti-abortion rights club for not following school policy. The dispute arose over the posting of flyers that allegedly violated the student’s First Amendment and Equal Access Act rights. The school argued its actions were content-neutral, suspending the club only for policy reasons. A spokesperson for Noblesville Schools expressed satisfaction with the ruling, highlighting the district's support for varied student clubs. A pro-life advocacy group criticized the decision as undermining free speech rights.

stories.headline: 'Bam Bam is my world'
stories.summary: Angel Santiago, Logan Square resident, was reunited with Bam Bam, his legally blind dachshund and emotional support dog, stolen in June from his home. The dog was found near Chicago police precincts and in good health, thanks to support from online communities and pet rescue groups. Santiago expressed deep emotions over Bam Bam's recovery, highlighting the strong bond and the dog's importance in his life.

stories.headline: Growing tension over CPS budget
stories.summary: Chicago Board of Education President Sean Harden has challenged the district's proposed budget amid doubts about reliance on revenue from special taxing districts to close a $734 million deficit. The tension highlights a standoff between Harden and Chicago Public Schools' CEO Macquline King, who counters the agenda of former Chicago Teachers Union organizer Johnson advocating for borrowing to address budget woes. This divide between elected and mayoral-appointed board members showcases the struggle over balancing the district's finances.

stories.headline: RTA may transfer $74M from Metra, Pace to CTA
stories.summary: Regional transportation officials may transfer $74 million from Metra and Pace to the Chicago Transit Authority (CTA) to delay catastrophic cuts to the city's transit system. The Regional Transportation Authority board is expected to vote on this measure to prevent severe service reductions next year while transit agencies await additional state funding. This effort aims to help maintain transit operations across all three agencies struggling with funding shortfalls.

stories.headline: Voter rolls show stark losses for Democrats
stories.summary: The Democratic Party is facing a significant decline in voter registration across the U.S. before elections, losing ground to Republicans in multiple states. Analysis by The New York Times reveals that Democrats lost voters in every state between the 2020 and 2024 elections, with a notable four-year swing toward Republicans adding up to 4.5 million voters. This shift may impact political power in battleground and blue states, indicating a challenging landscape for the Democratic Party.

stories.headline: President’s mail-in vote stance spurs fight
stories.summary: President Donald Trump's push to end absentee voting has sparked criticism and legal challenges, with advocacy groups and election-law experts arguing that the president cannot change election laws. Democrats prepare for a political fight around future election cycles. Mail-in voting is widespread and popular, with millions expected to use it in 2024. Advocates say it provides accessible voting options to many, including those with disabilities, and warn against removing it. The White House says Trump prioritizes working with lawmakers on mail-in voting.

stories.headline: Retaliation from airline caterer alleged
stories.summary: An airline catering worker in Phoenix claimed retaliation from his employer after he complained about unsafe working conditions related to local heat and safety violations at Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport. The employee was disciplined with a suspension for a safety violation. The dispute involves the company LSG Sky Chefs and the employee challenged the punishment with the Arizona Industrial Commission, alleging retaliation for speaking out. The company maintains the incident was minor and not harassment, while the worker and union support say otherwise. The city has adopted a heat safety ordinance recently.

stories.headline: Hurricane Erin churns up seas
stories.summary: Hurricane Erin is causing dangerous high tides, coastal flooding advisories, and rip currents along the U.S. East Coast. It is a Category 2 hurricane moving north with weakened winds but is expected to continue to create tropical-storm-force winds and life-threatening waves along the East Coast beaches for up to 48 hours or more. Residents and beachgoers are warned against swimming due to hazardous conditions as the storm moves toward North Carolina and beyond.

stories.headline: D.C. restaurants suffer amid federal crackdown
stories.summary: D.C. restaurants are experiencing declines in reservations and staff during the summer season as federal law enforcement efforts increase in the city. Operators report lower revenue and warn that the crackdown, intended to curb crime, is impacting business during a vital period for local dining establishments.

stories.headline: Putin had a good hand. Then it got overplayed.
stories.summary: The article analyzes the dueling summits over Ukraine involving Russia and the US, highlighting President Vladimir Putin's hard-line approach and resistance to compromise despite military setbacks and economic challenges. It concludes that Putin overplayed his hand, misjudging Trump's response and facing growing diplomatic and economic pressure.

stories.headline: Hamas signals new willingness to compromise
stories.summary: Hamas announced a new ceasefire agreement following diplomatic efforts between Egyptian, Israeli, and Palestinian officials. This development aims to de-escalate tensions in Gaza after recent conflict, with Hamas indicating possible openness to further negotiations alongside regional stakeholders.

stories.headline: Most D.C. residents oppose takeover of police, poll finds
stories.summary: A Washington Post-Charter School poll reveals a majority of D.C. residents oppose President Donald Trump's plan to federalize local law enforcement and provide a large federal law enforcement presence in the city. Poll results show clear disagreement with Trump's law enforcement overhaul rhetoric among residents, particularly about potential impacts on the community.

stories.headline: DOJ demands sweeping info on care for trans minors
stories.summary: The Justice Department is demanding extensive medical records related to care for transgender minors, including hospital, therapy, and drug manufacturer documents. This action is part of an ongoing probe into the care protocols for transgender youth, intensifying scrutiny on related medical and legal practices.

stories.headline: Hegseth security strains agency
stories.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth's unusually large personal security detail is straining Army agency resources, with top Defense Department officials noting the complexity and scale of protecting his family residences across multiple states. This has caused operational challenges and concerns within the agency.

stories.headline: Superiors tried to curb cop’s testimony
stories.summary: The Michigan State Police and Attorney General’s Office attempted to limit the testimony of a detective involved in a $58 million lawsuit against the state police. Detective Sgt. Jacquelyn Stasiak reportedly faced threats of job loss or criminal charges if she revealed certain information obtained through subpoenas. She ultimately hired outside legal counsel amid the dispute.

stories.headline: Alleged ‘terrorist’ to speak in Detroit
stories.summary: A Palestinian prisoner, freed as part of an Israel-Hamas hostage exchange, is scheduled to speak at the Detroit People’s Conference for Palestine, causing concern among some Jewish Americans who consider him a terrorist. The conference organizers announced the event, emphasizing the prisoner’s background and the controversy surrounding his past conviction and imprisonment in Israel.

stories.headline: Gravely injured in Gaza, kids find healing in Mich.
stories.summary: Children who suffered severe injuries in Israeli strikes in Gaza are receiving physical therapy and rehabilitation in Michigan. The story highlights the journey of young boys, including Waheed Al Ghalban and Mohammed Eid, who are overcoming the trauma of war and aiming to rebuild their lives despite their physical challenges. They are being helped by the nonprofit Heal Palestine in Dearborn Heights.

stories.headline: Fugitive ex-cop arrested 4 months after fleeing
stories.summary: Joshua Roelofs, a former cop accused of causing two men's deaths in a fatal drunken-driving crash, was apprehended in Colombia after evading capture for four months. He returned to the US and was arrested in Tampa, facing charges of DUI manslaughter connected to a 2022 incident. Authorities continue investigating the involvement of others linked to the case.

stories.headline: DeSantis: Trump isn’t trying to ban mail voting in Fla.
stories.summary: Florida Governor Ron DeSantis disputes claims that President Donald Trump wants to ban mail voting in Florida. DeSantis explained that Trump's concerns focus on states that send mail ballots to all voters, which Florida does not. He emphasized the importance of election integrity and rejected the notion that Florida bans mail voting altogether, noting ongoing distinctions in voting system policies.

stories.headline: St. Pete urges tenants facing water shutoff to move out
stories.summary: Residents at The Morgan apartment complex in St. Petersburg risk water shutoff due to the landlord’s unpaid $350,000 water bill. The city has issued an ultimatum to pay the bill by August 21 or face water shutoff. With combined unpaid water bills exceeding $700,000 among Lurin Real Estate Holdings’ properties, tenants may be forced to leave if utilities are cut off. City enforcement officials have notified residents of possible impacts.

stories.headline: Records provide more details about who’s held and how long
stories.summary: A month into his detention at Alligator Alcatraz, Daniell Ortiz Piñeda continues his legal fight for asylum or to be released. Nearly 2 in 5 immigrants listed in early July as being detained or headed to the facility remained detainees at the end of the month, according to reports. The records clarify that many migrants held had no criminal charges or convictions but were fighting cases in immigration courts.

stories.headline: Amazon may buy Gorham parcel for $4M. Is that a good deal for the town?
stories.summary: A proposal to sell 94 acres in Gorham to Amazon for $4 million sparked debate among town officials and residents. While the sale could net a small profit on the land, concerns remain over the project's full economic impact and residential property tax implications. The Town Council is reviewing the deal amid ongoing discussions about public input and development benefits.

stories.headline: GOP-controlled House in Texas approves new maps for more seats in Congress
stories.summary: Texas Republicans approved new congressional maps to add five new seats in the U.S. House of Representatives, responding to a mid-decade revision prompted by President Donald Trump. This decision intensifies the political battle over redistricting ahead of next year's election, with Democrats gearing up for a significant challenge.

stories.headline: 'It shows I can compete with the guys out here.' Up against the pros, local teen plays like one
stories.summary: Jack Quinn, a 17-year-old from Randolph, posted a 3-under par 67 to secure a couple of titles at Charlie's Maine Open golf tournament. Playing on his home course, Quinn tied for 10th place overall and proved himself competitive among professional and amateur players, showing strong performance despite occasional challenges during the rounds.

stories.headline: How SNAP eligibility cuts will impact kids’ access to nutrition
stories.summary: Maine has committed to funding free lunch for students regardless of federal cuts to SNAP over the next two years. However, changes in food assistance regulations mean that more of the financial burden will fall on the state. While free school lunch remains available, cuts from the federal government have impacted food access for kids outside of school, with potential long-term effects on federal funding for meal programs.

stories.headline: Downtown Wells Fargo properties sold for $32M
stories.summary: After more than two years of efforts to consolidate Des Moines metro employees on its West Des Moines campus, Wells Fargo sold off its former downtown office complex. The seven parcels were sold for $32 million to DMCREI LLC, represented by Gordon Glade of Grand Island, Nebraska. The sale involved more than 850,000 square feet of floorspace, including a notable 11-story building and a historic three-story structure dating from 1910. Wells Fargo declined to comment on the sale.

stories.headline: Attack on mail-in voting stirs fight: Trump has no legal role over running elections
stories.summary: President Donald Trump's recent push to end absentee voting has sparked significant criticism and debate about the nation's election rules ahead of the next mid-term and presidential campaigns. Experts confirm the president has no legal authority in governing elections, and advocacy groups have threatened lawsuits aimed at blocking Trump's efforts. With mail-in voting expected to be widely used in 2024, this dispute highlights broader tensions around election administration and legal jurisdiction.

stories.headline: BIN BUSTER: Record corn crop forecast for Iowa, even with rain, derecho
stories.summary: Despite hurricane-strength winds and near-record rainfall, Iowa farmers are expected to harvest their biggest corn crop ever this fall, with the U.S. Department of Agriculture and agricultural experts projecting Iowa to bring in nearly 2.9 billion bushels. Falling just short of a record 16.7-billion-bushel U.S. crop, Iowa's crop will likely still break records despite the damage from wet, humid conditions and storms, with several farmers noting this being the biggest crop they will see.

stories.headline: Employee fatally shot outside LR preschool
stories.summary: A fatal shooting occurred outside Little Rock's Rockefeller Early Childhood Center involving an employee who was shot in a parking lot on Wednesday afternoon. The victim was in a relationship with a man arrested on capital murder charges in connection to the case. The incident has triggered school lockdowns and investigations by local authorities, with the community expressing grief and concern.

stories.headline: Trump calls on Fed governor to resign her post
stories.summary: President Donald Trump has publicly called for Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook to resign amidst concerns over her investigation related to the mortgage finance system, including her role on the board of a mortgage giant and alleged conflicts of interest. The issue has raised questions about political influence and regulatory oversight involving Cook's ties and her actions during her tenure.

stories.headline: Sanders picks 6 for reconstituted library board
stories.summary: Governor Sarah Huckabee Sanders appointed six new board members to the nearly empty Arkansas State Library Board. The shake-up follows legislation requiring the board's reconstitution, with new members announced to fill the void left by terminated appointees and establish a full slate following changes prompted by Act 903 of 2025.

stories.headline: Texas House OKs new map
stories.summary: Texas Republicans approved new congressional maps that could add up to five new seats in the House of Representatives, marking the first big step toward redistricting under Republican Governor Greg Abbott. The move aims to strengthen the GOP's hold on Texas delegations in the 2026 midterm elections, though it has drawn criticism and legal scrutiny regarding its impact on fair representation.

stories.headline: Senator urges halt to prison payments
stories.summary: A state senator is calling for the state to halt payments to a California-based company steering the new prison project in Franklin County until representatives agree to meet with elected officials. The senator also supports a petition-backed citizens' complaint about the high prison payments and insists on better oversight and transparency.

stories.headline: Texas House OKs new maps
stories.summary: The Texas House approved new congressional maps that are expected to give Republicans a larger edge in the 2026 elections through partisan gerrymandering. This move, pushed by President Trump and GOP leaders, aims to create more GOP congressional seats despite protests from Democrats and others concerned about the fairness of redistricting. The maps still require approval by the GOP-controlled Senate and Governor Greg Abbott.

stories.headline: Governor won’t be ‘bullied’
stories.summary: Federal Reserve Governor Lisa Cook stated she will not resign despite calls on social media by former President Trump and others accusing her of misconduct related to mortgage fraud. Cook emphasized standing firm in her position despite the accusations. The situation highlights ongoing tensions surrounding federal regulators and political pressures following the administration of Trump.

stories.headline: Drugstores' dispute moves to federal court
stories.summary: A dispute involving a contract cancellation by a major pharmacy benefit manager is moving to federal court, potentially jeopardizing a chain of rural Pennsylvania pharmacies. Martella Pharmacies in Johnstown has filed a petition with the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania to stop the termination of their contract, which could otherwise force the pharmacies out of business.
people: Cambria County Common Pleas Judge Michael A. Carbonara

stories.headline: CMU reduces its expenses by $33 million
stories.summary: Carnegie Mellon University announced a $33 million reduction in expenses for the current fiscal year, driven by challenges in higher education and financial pressures. President Farnam Jahanian stated the university remains financially strong despite these cuts, which include staff reductions and careful management of financial shortfalls. These cost reductions are intended to maintain CMU's financial stability in the face of ongoing uncertainties.

stories.headline: SHAPIRO STANDS UP FOR MAIL VOTING
stories.summary: Governor Josh Shapiro criticized President Donald Trump's efforts to restrict mail voting in Pennsylvania, stating that Trump's war on postal ballots will have no bearing on the state's voting processes. The push to bar mail-in voting was framed as a political movement with GOP support, while Shapiro and Democratic leaders advocated for expanded mail voting access to counteract the Republicans' strategy.

stories.headline: At Kennedy School, a worry eases
stories.summary: Harvard Kennedy School expects most foreign students back on campus this fall after previous years of remote study and disrupted international enrollment. The school has adapted to ongoing challenges and will continue programs like HKS Global, despite concerns about declining international student numbers due to political and global factors.

stories.headline: Cuts have some on edge in needy Miss.
stories.summary: In West Jackson, Mississippi, state reliance on federal aid faces cuts that threaten community programs and services. The affected areas are struggling through summer heat and recovering from tornado damage. The faith-based organization Voice of Calvary Ministries highlights the importance of environmental resilience and social programs for vulnerable residents.

stories.headline: Concession workers say they lose with AI
stories.summary: At Fenway Park and TD Garden, workers like Amanda Savage report losing tips and hours as AI-powered self-checkout systems and cashier-less stores replace human jobs. These technologies reduce the need for labor not just in transaction tasks but also in customer interactions, hurting workers' income and job security.

stories.headline: Israel moves on West Bank, Gaza
stories.summary: Israel approved new settlements in the West Bank and announced plans to take over Gaza City, ignoring international criticism and support for an independent Palestinian state. The moves raise concerns about the feasibility of a Palestinian state being erased. The plan includes accelerating military advances and a large housing project, with significant potentially negative humanitarian impacts.

stories.headline: Clean energy in America is struggling for survival
stories.summary: The growth of new wind and solar power in the U.S., alongside cheap clean energy, may be at risk due to regulatory and political challenges. President Donald Trump's administration has issued directives and orders limiting new solar and wind projects, promoting fossil fuel production, and dismantling Biden-era environmental measures. Despite public concern and encouragement for renewable energy, these federal policies threaten the viability of clean energy expansion.

stories.headline: Price of hospital services erratic
stories.summary: A new report from Trilliant Health reveals significant price variability for the same medical procedures across different hospitals and surgery centers, with total costs for knee and ankle replacements spanning from thousands to over a hundred thousand dollars depending on the location. This inconsistency can lead to large financial burdens for insured consumers, including big bills, loans, and medical debt. The study also noted discrepancies in hospital lists and linkages between prices and quality.

stories.headline: Texans move to California for trans child
stories.summary: Sunny Bryant, a young transgender activist from Texas, and her family have moved to California seeking a more supportive environment after facing challenges accessing medical care and rights in Texas. Sunny, who spoke out against restrictive trans rights bills in Texas, finds California a place where she can thrive. Her mother, Rebekah Bryant, highlights their family's fight for acceptance and the need for Sunny to grow up without being criminalized for her identity.

stories.headline: Trump war on mail-in voting gets blowback
stories.summary: President Donald Trump's latest push to end absentee voting has faced criticism and legal challenges, with election-law experts stating a president has no authority to govern elections. Advocacy groups are preparing lawsuits as the focus shifts toward the 2026 and 2028 election cycles. Mail-in voting remains popular and widespread, but states have varying rules and requirements impacting voter participation.

stories.headline: Free meals this year are uncertain. Here’s some lunch advice.
stories.summary: With Michigan families preparing for the return to school amid uncertainties in the state's K-12 budget, the future of universal free school-provided breakfasts and lunches remains unclear. Experts advise considering children's preferences and dietary needs when deciding to pack lunch or to opt for school meals which may be limited in availability and variety.

stories.headline: More than 100 bridges at risk of closure by 2035
stories.summary: An I-94 bridge in southwest Michigan, among others, has been rated in poor condition due to insufficient funding for maintenance. Over 100 state trunkline bridges face potential closure by 2035, impacting millions of drivers and communities. State officials warn that without a comprehensive transportation funding package, highway programs and road funding will decline substantially, risking critical infrastructure.

stories.headline: Coal plant order will cost 11 states’ utility customers
stories.summary: Tens of millions of dollars in costs are expected to rise for Michigan and ten other states due to a Trump administration order permitting Michigan coal-fired power plant to run. Consumers Energy and federal energy regulators are in discussion over the order, while consumer groups oppose it, warning about the financial impact to utility bills across the Midwest.

stories.headline: NY State Fair butter sculpture unveiled
stories.summary: The 57th annual New York State Fair butter sculpture was revealed at the New York State Fairgrounds in Geddes, inspired by the 125th anniversary of "The Wonderful Wizard of Oz." The sculpture features a cow emblazoned with 'Dairy Defies Gravity' and surrounded by figures representing themes from the story, paying homage to New York author L. Frank Baum. Made from 800 pounds of butter, it is sponsored by Wegmans and created by artists Jim Victor and Marie Pelton.

stories.headline: Wind, solar energy at risk under Trump
stories.summary: The renewable energy sector, particularly wind and solar power, faces potential setbacks under policies favored by Donald Trump. The administration’s stance raises concerns about the sustainability and growth of green energy projects in the U.S., putting recent advancements at risk and causing uncertainty for the industry.

stories.headline: Cannabis dispensaries sue NY let them open too close to schools
stories.summary: New York cannabis dispensaries mistakenly opened too close to schools due to misinterpretation of state rules on minimum distance. After realizing the error, 152 dispensaries filed a lawsuit challenging the state’s interpretation. The state has promised to overlook the mistake temporarily but aims to establish clearer regulations next year to avoid grandfathering affected sites. Legal representatives emphasize the significant financial risk to dispensaries if licenses are revoked.

stories.headline: Trump takes ‘perfecto’ approach to design
stories.summary: Donald Trump, once a real estate mogul, has brought his flamboyant design style to the White House’s redevelopment, including gold and lavish décor. After returning to the White House 50 years since his real estate moves, he has transformed areas with gold appliqués, gilded mirrors, and elaborate artworks, continuing his love for luxurious and extravagant aesthetics.

stories.headline: Texas House approves redrawn maps
stories.summary: The Texas House passed a contentious partisan congressional map that favors Republicans and is likely to benefit President Donald Trump in the next U.S. House elections. The map passed 88-52 largely along party lines after months of political dispute. The state Senate is expected to vote on the map soon before sending it to Governor Greg Abbott for signature. The redrawing is the first step in a potentially prolonged redistricting struggle between Republicans and Democrats, with a referendum possible in November.

stories.headline: Frat hazing incident at UTC results in no charges
stories.summary: Investigations into a severe hazing incident at the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga involving Alpha Iota chapter of Kappa Sigma fraternity found no criminal charges will be filed. Despite evidence that pledges suffered injuries due to dangerous activities like being dragged behind a car and struck with objects, neither fraternity leadership nor campus police took action to stop the incident. The case highlights ongoing issues around fraternity hazing and accountability.
people: Alpha Iota chapter of Kappa Sigma

stories.headline: Fewer people reading for fun, study concludes
stories.summary: A new study from University College London and University of Florida shows a steady decline in Americans reading for pleasure over the past two decades. The percentage of people reporting reading for fun dropped from 28% in 2004 to 16% in 2023, with researchers attributing declines to multiple factors such as increased screen time, social media, and other technology. The study calls for further research to better understand the causes and confirms a concerning cultural trend away from reading for enjoyment.

stories.headline: Builders get win in plan for growth
stories.summary: Hamilton County Commission narrowly approved amendments in a 6-5 vote to Plan Hamilton aimed at compromising between development and preservation. The changes, sponsored by Commissioner Lee Helton, include adding density in agricultural areas and new sewage systems, while requiring sidewalks and larger setbacks for subdivisions. The plan was supported mainly by home builders and developers, but faced opposition from some rural residents concerned about density and floodplain development.

stories.headline: POLICE KILL MAN AFTER CHASE
stories.summary: A St. Ann police officer fatally shot a man early Wednesday after chasing him to a Bel-Ridge home where he allegedly pulled a gun. The deceased was identified as Troy Hamilton, 37, whose wife expressed heartbreak over his death. Police reported physical altercation and gun involvement during the incident which occurred around 12:15 a.m. near St. Charles Rock and North and South roads.

stories.headline: City’s emergency chief fired after siren debacle
stories.summary: Sarah Russell, St. Louis' emergency management chief, has been fired after a failure to properly deploy storm sirens before a May 16 tornado. No official reason was given for her dismissal, and Russell has not responded to requests for comment. A spokesperson for the mayor stated that the city remains committed to ensuring service and leadership during the transition period.

stories.headline: Man infected by amoeba at Lake of the Ozarks dies
stories.summary: A man who contracted a rare brain infection from an amoeba in Lake of the Ozarks has died. The infection was confirmed to be caused by Naegleria fowleri, a microbe found in warm freshwater such as lakes and ponds. The man had been hospitalized since August 10 and died on Tuesday at a St. Louis area hospital. Health officials reminded the public that water contaminated with this parasite is extremely dangerous, as it enters through the nose and infects the brain.

stories.headline: FBI will increase agents in St. Louis
stories.summary: The FBI is sending more agents and personnel to St. Louis, boosting numbers to their highest point in years. This move is part of an effort by the Trump administration to strengthen federal presence and violent crime-fighting capabilities in the city. The FBI Director highlighted the importance of cooperating with local law enforcement to tackle violent criminals. However, the move has sparked some controversy regarding immigration and federal actions in American cities.
